renderLines.label: Connect events chronologically with lines (for each entity)

text.label: Text
text.value: Else Röhr was born on August 2, 1907 in Magdeburg. As a young woman, she had a relationship with a Jewish man.

text.label: Text
text.value: After the National Socialists came to power and people of the Jewish religion were increasingly marginalized and discriminated against, the man decided to leave Germany. The couple then separated.

text.label: Text
text.value: Else suffered from the failed relationship and her condition deteriorated. She hardly ate and slept little. In February 1936, she sought help at Magdeburg-Sudenburg Hospital...

text.label: Text
text.value: Heinrich Bunke on the other side joined the NSDAP when he was 23 and was sent around in Germany to receive an emergency license to practice medicine during the war. In October 1940, he was assigned to the Bernburg Euthanasia Center, where he worked until October 1941...

question.label: Question
question.value: Which falsified reason was stated for Else Röhr's death in this death certificate?

text.label: Text
text.value: These plans of the “Bernburg Recovery and Nursing Home” are part of a set of plans drawn in November 1945. Based on the information written on them, the plans are thought to have been created as part of documenting the operations at the killing centre, though this is not yet verified.

text.label: Text
text.value: When the arrival of the patients at the front was observed by bystanders, a garage for several transport buses was built behind the building. A high barrier was also built to conceal the arrival of the buses

Military service in motor vehicle division in Hanover

Assistant position at State Women's Clinic in Celle

data-roehr-bunke-bio-001.text:
Dr. Heinrich Bunke was born on July 24, 1914, in Wohlde, Celle District, Lower Saxony. He completed his A-levels and pursued medical studies, later becoming an emergency doctor. Before World War II, he was stationed in Ratzeburg with a replacement battalion.

During the war, Bunke was conscripted and, due to his medical education, received an emergency license to practice medicine. In October 1940, he was assigned to the Bernburg Euthanasia Center, where he worked until October/November 1941. His role involved determining false causes of death for patients subjected to the euthanasia program. Bunke claimed he was unaware of any wrongdoing during his tenure.

After leaving Bernburg, Bunke joined Organization Todt. Post-war, he secured an assistant position at the State Women"s Clinic in Celle and later established his gynecological practice in 1951. Arrested in April 1962 for his wartime activities, he was released under conditions and continued practicing medicine.

Bunke"s trial began on October 3, 1966, resulting in an acquittal in 1967 due to his alleged ignorance of the program"s illegality. However, this verdict was overturned in 1970. Despite claiming health issues to avoid a retrial, Bunke continued working. Eventually, he was convicted in 1987 for aiding and abetting murder in at least 9,200 cases and sentenced to three years in prison, serving 18 months before his release.

Dr. Heinrich Bunke passed away on September 16, 2001, in Celle.

data-roehr-bunke-bio-002.text:
Else Röhr was born on August 2, 1907, in Magdeburg. As a young woman, she had a relationship with a Jewish man, but their relationship ended when he decided to leave Germany following the rise of the National Socialists and the increasing marginalization and discrimination against Jewish people.

The end of this relationship deeply affected Else, leading to a decline in her mental and physical health. She sought help at Magdeburg-Sudenburg Hospital in February 1936, where she was diagnosed with 'juvenile schizophrenia.' Following this diagnosis, she was transferred to the Neuhaldensleben State Sanatorium on February 27, 1936.

Her condition led to a decision for forced sterilization, approved on June 4, 1936, and performed on November 24, 1936. Despite her physical recovery, her mental illness was confirmed on December 5, 1936. She continued to receive care at the Haldensleben State Hospital until February 18, 1937, after which she was cared for at home briefly until April 3, 1937, when she was readmitted to the state mental hospital.

On November 15, 1940, Else and other patients were transferred to the Uchtspringe State Hospital. A visit from relatives was refused on March 28, 1941. Shortly after, on April 2, 1941, Else was transferred to Bernburg, where she was murdered in the gas chambers on the same day.
